content.title: Buerger Disease (Thromboangiitis Obliterans)
content.summary: Non-atherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory disease affecting small and medium vessels of the extremities, strongly associated with tobacco use in young patients.

definitions.definition: Segmental, thrombotic, occlusive, non-atherosclerotic vascular disease affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities, predominantly in young male smokers.

Clinical diagnostic criteria: (1) smoking history, (2) onset before age 50, (3) infrapopliteal occlusion, (4) upper extremity involvement or phlebitis migrans, (5) absence of atherosclerotic risk factors except smoking.

key_concepts.explanation: Intermittent claudication of foot/arch, rest pain, ischemic ulcers of digits. Superficial thrombophlebitis (migratory). Raynaud's phenomenon in 40%. Upper extremity involvement in 30-50%. Bilateral disease common.
Segmental occlusions of small/medium vessels with normal proximal arteries. 'Corkscrew' collaterals (helical vessels around occlusions). Absence of proximal atherosclerotic disease. Skip lesions.

Continued smoking leads to 40-50% amputation rate. Complete cessation halts disease progression in 90%+. Even reduction insufficient - must be complete abstinence. Includes all tobacco and cannabis products.

Bypass rarely possible due to distal disease and poor runoff. Sympathectomy may provide symptomatic relief. Iloprost (prostacyclin analog) for rest pain and ulcer healing. Amputation for irreversible ischemia.

evidence.citation: Olin et al., TAO Natural History, 2000
evidence.finding: Amputation rate 25% if smoking continues vs 5% if complete cessation is achieved
Autologous bone marrow cell implantation showed promise for improving ABI and pain in Buerger disease

clinical_pearls: Consider Buerger disease in any young smoker with distal extremity ischemia
Upper extremity involvement distinguishes from typical PAD
Superficial thrombophlebitis in a young smoker should raise suspicion
Cotinine levels can confirm smoking status - patients may underreport
Cannabis smoking may also cause or exacerbate Buerger disease
learning_objectives: Apply Shionoya criteria for diagnosis of Buerger disease
Recognize angiographic findings characteristic of TAO
Explain why smoking cessation is critical for disease management
Describe limited role of revascularization in Buerger disease
State the role of prostacyclin analogs in treatment
